Award.AwardTitle: Interfacing Major Field Experiments with Physical Parameterizations in Atmospheric General Circulation Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important physical process that must be well represented in climate models is horizontal momentum transport. This is the motivation for this project, the goal of which is to improve and validate momentum transport schemes in global climate models. Toward this end, the PI will develop integrated datasets, from major field campaigns, of large-scale forcing and sub-grid sources and sinks of horizontal momentum. These will be used to force and evaluate Single Column Models (SCM), Cloud System Resolving Models (CSRM), and physical parameterizations to improve General Circulation Models (GCM).

The Principal Investigator (PI) will use a new variational approach, based on his group's previous research on advective tendencies of temperature and water using balloon sounding arrays, to analyze atmospheric momentum budgets in which column-integrated conservations of dry air and water vapor mass, enthalpy and momentum will be preserved. Apparent momentum sources and sinks will be derived for four field experiments in the tropics, the Tropical Ocean Global Atmospheres/Coupled Ocean Atmosphere Response Experiment (TOGA-COARE), The Kwajalein Experiment (KWAJEX), The South China Sea Monsoon Experiment (SCSMEX), and the Tropical Warm Pool - International Cloud Experiment (TWP-ICE) and several in the middle latitudes (the Department of Energy (Atmospheric Radiation Program Southern Great Plains (ARM-SGP) sites). Uncertainties of the data products will be quantified through sensitivity studies and Observational Simulation System Experiments (OSSE).

The developed integrated data products will be used to answer three main questions: (a) Under what large-scale conditions is subgrid momentum transport upscale and under what conditions is it downscale? (b) How do GCM parameterizations of momentum transport compare with observations? (c) How can we improve the momentum source/sink parameterizations in atmospheric models.

Broader impacts of this work are in advancing our understanding of atmospheric momentum sources and sinks from observations and their better parameterizations in climate models, which is necessary for them to predict future climate changes, and of the mechanism of atmospheric variability in the tropics. A postdoc and a graduate student will be mentored and trained in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric measurements taken in field experiments from different measurement platforms, such as satellites, radars, balloon soundings and from different instruments, such as anemometers, thermometers, hygrometers, and radiometers almost always lack consistency among each other due to unavoidable instrument errors and different sampling methods. These inconsistencies can cause significant problems to the users of the measurements. One example is the typical lack of consistency of these measurements in conserving column integrated mass of air, water vapor, energy and moment – the vertically integrated horizontal transport of these properties calculated from balloon soundings are typically not equal to the integrated source and sinks terms measurement from the surface and on satellites. When the transport terms are used in atmosphere models, they will impact the results of numerical models, compounding the errors attributable to models.

 

In this project, we derived the atmospheric horizontal transport of properties (water vapor, static energy and momentum) by using a variational analysis algorithm with known physical constraints. The principle is based on minimum adjustments to direct measurements, so that errors are corrected and physical consistencies are maintained. The magnitudes of the relative adjustments among different variables (winds, temperature, and water vapor) at different stations, times and pressure levels, are found to be small relative to measurement errors.  We carried out the analysis for the atmospheric field campaigns of KWAJEX, SCSMEX, LBA, TOGA-COARE, M-PACE, and TWP-ICE The analyzed data have been made easily accessible to the public through the web (http://atmgcm.msrc.sunysb.edu/iops.html), and have been widely used in the community of cloud-resolving models and single-column models.  These include the study of atmospheric convection, clouds, precipitation, and the macrophysical and microphysical processes of clouds, including the aerosol indirect effects, as well as their impact on simulated climate in numerical models.

 

In one of the applications of these data,  we introduced a numerical scheme  into the Community Atmospheric Model (CAM) to calculate the rate of condensation of atmospheric water vapor to liquid or ice occurring  in a fraction of the GCM grid box. The key element of the scheme is that the fractional condensation should reduce the grid scale relative humidity that should be consistent with the increase of stratiform cloud amount. As a result, cloud water and cloud amount are coupled, which overcomes a major flaw in earlier versions of the CAM. The scheme was used in CAM3 and CAM4. It theoretical formulation is also used in the newest version of the CAM (CAM5).

 

Results from this project have led to more accurate characterization of the atmospheric dynamic and thermodynamic fields. They have allowed modelers to use the observed atmospheric transport data to force their models so that biases attributable to model errors can be isolated, leading to improved atmospheric models for weather prediction and climate change research.
